div.head: EGYPT EXPLORATION FUND
div.p: The proceedings at the recent meeting of the Egypt Exploration Fund, of which a detailed account appeared in our columns, add a fascinating chapter to the story of archaeological research. They show, says the "Morning Post," that the spirit which led Schliemann to realize his desire to lay bare the site of ancient Troy is still no less active among scholars of the present. But if Schliemann may be said to have led the way in the modern exploration of ancient sites his successors have derived enormous assistance from the stores of scientific knowledge which have been accumulated since his day. The close investigation of the Agrean area has revealed civilizations extending into unplumbed antiquity. In particular the marvelous discoveries of Mr. Arthur Evans at Cnossos, in Crete, have necessitated a "reconstruction" of theory which is still the subject of much controversial discussion. In Egypt the same admirable work is being carried on with results which are obvious even to the casual visitor of the great national museums in Europe and America. The part played by the Egypt Exploration Fund is well known to scholars and laymen alike. Among the first of its successes was the discovery in 1883, by M. Naville, of Pithom-Succoth, one of the "store cities" built by the forced labor of the Hebrews during the oppression. Two years later the investigations of Professor Flinders Petrie at Naukratis threw a flood of light upon Greek arts, trade, manufactures and writing. In recent years, the excavations conducted by Messrs. Grenfell and Hunt on the site of Oxyrynchus have brought to light a quantity of Greek papyri of incalculable value to students of ancient literature, sacred as well as profane. Among the texts which have already been published, the Ingia or sayings of Jesus are perhaps the most famous. At the last meeting Dr. Grenfell was able to announce a further batch of discoveries on the same site. The find which must naturally have most interest for the general reader is concerned with a new Gospel fragment, written on a leaf out of a vellum book, which was found in one of the later mounds of the town with papyri of the fourth and sixth centuries. The subject of the fragment is a dramatic narration of a meeting of Jesus and His Disciples with a Parise in the Temple at Jerusalem. While the nature and value of this gospel, which according to Dr. Grenfell must have been in narrative form, resembling that of the Synoptists, are still matters for future discussion, the learned discoverer is able to state that "like the two series of Oxyrynchus sayings, the new fragment is likely to claim niche in the fabric of early Christian literature for itself, reminding us, on the one hand, how extraordinary varied and striking in character the early uncanonical traditions connected with our Lord were, and on the other hand how miserably imperfect, judge by an absolute standard, our knowledge of those traditions is and is likely to remain. Among the more important discoveries in profane literature a manuscript some 900 line long of a new Greek historian is perhaps the most noticeable. The period covered by the fragment is the two years BC 396-5, shortly after the close of the Peloponnesian War. The account of the campaigns of Agesilaus in Asia Minor discloses a quantity of fresh information which supplement and corrects the narrative of Xenophon. The most valuable part of the papyrus is according to Dr. Grenfell, that which deals with the Constitution of Boeotia and the revelation of Thebes to the federated cities. The weight of available evidence seems to point to the author of the fragment being Cratippus but, says Dr. Grenfell, "call him by whatever name you will, his work ranks near after the treatise of Aristotle upon the constitution of Athens amongst modern addition to Greek history". Among the others now brought to light are parts of five pieces of Pindar (a department of this poet's work which hitherto has been almost unknown parts of a lost tragedy of Euripides and a commentary on the second book of The cydides, portions of Platonic dialogues, the Panegyricus of Isocrates, and the speech of Demosthenes against Borotus. Another great find was a group of fragments of the writings of Greek lyric poets, among who Sappho and Bacchylides are prominently mentioned. To discuss detail these additions to our knowledge of ancient Greek literature is obviously impracticable. But it is certain that their value in extending the area classical learning can hardly be exaggerated. Turning to another branch of the Fund's worse of the excavations conducted by M. Naville is King Mentuhetep's Temple at Deir-el-Baharia, noticeable as having enriched our acquaintance with a Dynasty about which our information was very scanty. The investigation of the passage, which, if surmise be correct, may lead to the tomb of the King, will be undertaken in the forthcoming season. On all grounds it is to be hope I that the Fund will receive the support necessary for the prosecution of the valuable work.

div.head: Plague of Locusts
div.p: Maize per ardeb has reached P.T. 48 at Kassala owing to the recent ravages of locusts.

div.head: Athletics in the Sudan
div.p: A new athletic club has been started at Khartonm. Tbe inauguration was attended by the Sirdar.

div.head: Bedouins Census
div.p: The census of the Bedonins is the first to be taken in the case of the tribes scattered over the Arabian desert East of the Nile.

div.head: Sale of Hotel
div.p: M. Allvund stated to have sold the Hotel de la Poste for 210,000 francs to M.S. Romeo, of Port Said. who has taken it over.

div.head: Jewish Benevolent Society
div.p: The Alexandria Jewish Benevolent Society "Gmelet Heved" will give a theatrical performance this evening at the Z'zinas Theatre.

div.head: A Nile Wreck
div.p: A large Nile boat full of cereals and with twenty-five passengers on board has been wrecked near Abnoud. Two persons were drowned.

div.head: Anti-Rabic Institute for Port Said
div.p: The Governor of Port Said has decided to institute an anti-rabic institute, similar to that at Cairo, next year owing to the number of cases of hydrophobia.

div.head: A Special Cargo
div.p: Tbe P. & O. Company's steamer India, which is due at Port Said in a few days, is said to be carrying the following specie: for Port Said, bar silver £685; and Bombay, bar gold £89,250. coin gold £3.000, bar silver £62.000, and dollars silver £16,500.

div.head: Alexandria Casino Scheme
div.p: The Municipal Commission will discuss the question of the grant of a concession for a site for a Casino on the new quay at its forthcoming meeting next week. The application has been made by Mr. George Ralli, and it is hoped that a favorable decision will be arrived at soon.

div.head: Coal Imports
div.p: Tbe total imports of coal at Alexandria for the year into November 29 were 1,185 883 tons, of which 645,947 tons was Welsh, 2 1,088 Newcastle, 108,273 Scotch, 169,670 Yorkshire, and 60,955 other qualities. The imports for the same period last year were 985 669 tons.

div.head: A Prince Robbed
div.p: Mahmoud Midhat, a servant of Prince Heidar Pasha is now in custody at Cairo, having been arrested at Nazret El Borgi, in the Fasb Market. He lafe'y abreonded thither with money and jewellry belonging to his master, and was living under an assumed name.

div.head: The Choubra Tragedy.
div.p: A fresh enquiry has been opened by M. de Reffye. French Consol at Cairo, into the circumstances attending the mysterious death of the Greek grocer Scopelitis. Tbe contents of the dossier will shortly be communicated to Mal're Garrivier, counsel for the young man Paillard.

div.head: Municpal Credits.
div.p: The Alexandria Municipal Commission has decided to open the following credits : L.E. 300 for the alignment of the new wing to be added to the west side of the Municipal building; L.E. 120 for the construction of a drain at Sidi Gaber; L.E. 150 for levelling the hillock before tha Mohamed Aly School, and L.B. 123 as a supplementary credit for the Park schemes.

div.head: Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: The wrestling match at the Alhambra Theatre last night were most interesting, all the matches wero vigorously contested. The following were the victors : 1. Carl Cylis beat Sanderfly (11 minutes). 2. Salasma-Haasib beat Noel le Gaulois (3 minutes) 3. Eigmann beat Sturm (4 minutes). 4.Osttinger beat Finisch (2 minutes). 5. Limousin and Schackman drawn. to be continued another day. This evening the following matches have been arranged: Milo v. Clement, Ahmed Aly v. Noel. Mohamed v. Cvlis, Eigmann v. Finish, Pons v. Vander Berg. Tomorrow there will be afternoon and evening contests, with 1,000 in prizes.

div.head: Honesty Rewarded
div.p: The nephew of a Port Said hairdresser, M.D. Vellardi, or the rue du Commerce, and an employe of the firm Del Mar, picked up a pearl necklace of the value of $1,500, belonging to the Princess Preteva of Cooch Bihar, a passenger by the P. & O. S.S. Arabia, which arrived at the Port Said on Wednesday last. The youth was sitting at the door of this uncle’s hairdressing establishment when he noticed the necklace on the foot path, and after some trouble succeeded on getting it restored to the Princess whose secretary rewarded the finder with 3?. ON the matter being brought to the notice of the Princess, her Highness sent $1 to M. Vellardi, who intends bringing an action against that lady for ten percent of the value of the object.

div.head: Egyptian State Railways
div.p: From 1st December the following will be the fares for rides in the train de luxe running between Cairo and Lexor and vice versa. Between Cairo and Beni Sonef P.T. 35; Miria P.T. 50; Assiout, P.T. 70; Sojag P.T. 90; Nag Hamadi, P.T. 90; Kepeb P.T. 100; Luxor P.T. 100..

DEATH OF SIR EDWARD REED
London. November 30.
Sir Edward James Reed, K.C.B., naval constructor, is dead. (Reuters)

Sir Edward Charles James Reed, K.C.B., FRS. J.P, was a man of versatile talents, having been a naval constructor, treasurer, politician, writer and poet. Born on the 20th September, 1830, he was educated at the School of Mathematics and Naval Construction, Portsmouth; was chief constructor of the Navy, 1863 70; Lord of the Treasury 1886; represented Pembroke 1874-1880, and Cardiff, 1880-1895. His publications were "Our Iron c’ad Ships’ 1869; "Letters from Russia,” 1875-76; "Japan,” 1880; "The Stability of Ships,” 1884; "Fort Minister, M.P.,” 1885; and "Modern Ships of War,” in which Admiral Simpson collaborated , 1888. He issued a volume of poems in 1902. He was knighted in 1880.

A RU8SIAN SCANDAL
GOVERNMENT DEAL IN WHEAT.
Sr. Petersburg, November 30.

Intense indignation is felt in the Volga provisoes, where famine is raging, owing tr the revelation that the Assistant Ministei of ths Interior, M. Gnrko, gave a contract for wheat, value £400 000. to a firm dealing in toilet requisites. He advanced the firm £80,000. The wheat naturally baa not been delivered, and tbs regular dealers declare now that it is impossible to deliver it in time to save the famioe-stricken. M. Gurko refused to give an explanation to a Council of Mi niaterv, stating that he would explain only to the Tsar. (Renter)

div.head: LAND VALUES.
div.p: In reply to those who are constantly enquiring as to the future prospects of the leading and companies doing business io Egypt, the following extract from the "Westminster Gazette" will be read with interest :—

"In spite of all the gloomy prophets, the prosperity grows more and more apparent every day. In Cairo, and also in the other principal towns, land, property, and manufactures continue to rise in value, and this state of things has lasted now for over three years, presenting an almost unparalleled case of the growth of national prosperity. Not only does the value of building sites increase, but it seems to do so on a uniform scale. In the more central parts of the town it may be given as 1, 1 1/2, 2, 2 1/2, 3, 3 1/2 and c; for the outlying districts the rise is about halved.
' It is difficult to gauge the extent of this increase, for, as prices go op, rents increase and demand continues to exceed supply in a very remarkable way.

"It is evident that an immense influx of pnpnlation is tak'ng plaoe io tbe Bgyptian Metropolis, and to far there has been no signWhich taxonomic domain includes multicellular photosynthetic organisms? See Concept 1.2 (Page) 1906-12-011906-12-01of plethora. Tbe popnlaoe serin i to grow in prosperity as it increaaei in number, jnat at it might do in a big Amorioao town.

"Tbe analogy is striking. As io Illinois and Loaisiana so in Egypt an enormously rich conntry has lain idle for oentorres ; but here whilethe land reste I, the popple were increasing, and as soon aa a pcaoetul rale supplanted the destructive influences of the past, as soon as ee-inrity sraa assured by tha comparion,'the f rroas lying dormant io the masa of the population ware set at liberty and now off-sr up an opportunity of nsefalness and profit which only needs managemeut to become most valuable.

"The development of town* it, we moat not forget, the direct ontooeae of the rnral develop moot, which io the tame way, though in a lesser degree, baa followed the same order of progre*sion. The oantts of this are many and need detailed treatment ; so that I will f ir the present oooteot myself by saying that it should be easy to oalonlate the rate of the development of rural properties, taking into consideration the natural conditions of 'he lind and the situation of each diaerio*. Tb-- balanoe will gradually establish itself here, and once the tosrn i* settled ths country will alsr regain ita equilibriom. "

Seolement, poor être juste, il tant reconnaître quo nous aurions dû avoir le don de la prophétie ponr ponvoir prédire que la lassitude de la petite sjécclation, dont le* position* étaient surchargées et dont les ré*li sations et lea allégements, qui étaient cor le point de commencer, devaent prodoire are certaine baisse, aurait fait inopinément place à cette frayeur qui s'est emparée, sans provoc* tion, dn découvert qui noos a vain ce moove- ment échevelé et cette hausse rapide et ontrée qce noos avons eoe pendant la semaine, comme conséquenco des rachat» qui ont en lien. Poor notre part noos avons été complètement désorientés par les événement de ces jours derniers ; mais, do bonne foi, o-t ce que dos contrad'c'ecrs n'ont pas été aos"-i surpris que noos I Qui pourrait dono soutenir qu'il »'atlen\ ,|jie qUI dait i ce qui s'est passé du jour au lendemain " et sortout qu'il soupçonnait l'importance du découvert qoi existait, avant que le* fait» aoivut venus noos la faire connal'n- t

Le fait i st que c'est un véritable coup de foudre que nous avons et que 'es haussiers eut eu la chance d'avoir une occasion ire») éréa et juste au bon m> ment, pour réaliser des béi é fices e place des sacrifie»- qu'ils étaient peut- être félidés è faite poor ré". >re leur fardeau.

Quant à l'a)lare du marché, elle a é é de» plo» étonnantes : cb> que c ô'ure a eu lit hausse sur i elle de la veille, sans aucune téao- tion intérimaire, au point que l'on pourrait dire que c'est presque d'emblée que leicoors out gagné le tallari et nn huitième qui représentent le résultat du mouvement de la semaine. Ao niveau auquel noos scmme*, cela eat très beau et dos hau»siers d'hier peuvent a'en féliciter. Comme cô-ore finale/le Mars eet à 19 5/32 et comma maximum noos avons pavé par le ooo rade 19 3/8 dans l'après midi de ce jour.

Ponr compléter mis rens'ii-riemenf» a»i marché, ajoutons que le • eh ffnt d'.IT.i traité a été oolossal et qua le découvert i Vt pas borné à quelque* gros bonnets d'Alex drie, mais que quelques Cairotes aussi on' une large part dans ce gâ'eao indigeste qui a ' T dû être avalé par 1er venueurs en blanc Kepé

der lea positions do leors adversaires. Comme conséquence naturelle donc, le danger appréhendé du chef des nouveaux haussiers ne sau- être réellement grand ni sérieux, uor noos résumer, nous dirons que noua partageons l'avis de oeox qui croient que noos allons avoir nne période de répit, en attendant que de rouvertx faits viennent guider notre mari hé. Toutefois, nous ne vouloux paa.caeber que l'imprerMon qui prévaut est que tonte haïr s» lér ei se est impossible pour le moment, et cr ia à la suite du fait constaté que, con- 'rsirtmei t au Courir eut dont l'abstention est quasi abro ue depuis quelquea jitrrVTAngle- erre, soit plus exactement les filateor» de fia de ce pays ont f»it' de nouveaux achats, -►et rond», et sans lésiner sur la question du •ri*. Il est vrai que les anglais sont moins pprovisinnnés que l«s continentaux ; mais, quand même, ia facilité avec laquelle ils ont admis la dernière hausse, cm fi-merait tout au iris les déj ê;bea reçue s il y a trois on quatre irs de Manchester et aunurçant que le» filés égyptiens étaient en amélioration. Malgré toot, es pendant, i ous persistons à te que si notre réco te est d«n* les 7 millions nB'Qantsrs, il nous testera toi joors un surplaa invendable»! ce uVat à des prix modérés.

Ce nouvel établissement a cela d* particulièrement avantageux que tout le capital con siate en aotioa*, sine aaoaoe part de foudstanr. Le conieil d'administration est déjà firmé. Nou

div.head: "INVESTMENTS."
div.p:
"Investments" introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are "Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them"; "Theory of Successful Speculation"; "How to start an Account" ; "The Advantages of 'Call Options'"; "Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities" ; "How to Invest in Mines"; "American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees"; "The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments" ; "General Principles for Investors" ; "Rules for Investors in Mines"; "General Principles for Speculators"; "Stock Exchange Terms," being a glossary for Market Operators; "Stock Exchange Parlance"; "Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money," and "Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities."

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT.
div.p: by Tender of about 400 Building Sites
The sites will l>u leasehold held nt Annual Rents on Building Lease for Eighty Year» from 1st January, 1907. Rents will bo payable only from date of acceptance of Tender.
The Lease will bo Perpetually Renewable at Revised Rents fixed in defaul toft Agreement by Arbitration at the end of each/term of yeara.
In fixing the revised rcnbrtfie vklue of Buildings erected by Lessees will Not be regarded ns a ground for Increase of Rent

Example: If a plot is leased'or a term of W) years from 1st January 1907 then on the expiration of that term the Lessee will havo a right (subject to observance of his convenant etc) to ohtaia a fresh lease for a further period of 60 years at a revised rent, and so on in perpetuity. The revised rent will be calculated on tlie value the site would bear if it were vacant building land*.
Offert are invited of Premiums for the Purchase of the above mention'd leasehold sites.
All offers must lie made by Tender, on the forms issued by the .Sudan Government, and must be received at Khartoum not later than 1st- January 1907.

Particulars of tho sites offered, Plan of the Town,'Conditions of Tender and Sgle, Form of Tender, specimen F'onn of I easy; etc., will on and after October 1st 1906 be open to inspection at the following places during the usual business hours :

div.head: GOUVERNEMENT DU SOUDAN
div.p: Concessions de Terrains a Batir a Port-Soudan
Le Gouvernement du Soudan va prochaine- ment disposer, par voie d'adjudication d'en- viron 400 parcelles de terrains a batir à Port- Soudan.

Les dites parcelles seront données à bail emphyteotique, pour une dure de 80 années à partir du ler Janvier 1907, moyennant loyer annuel, à charge pour le locataire de bâtir. Le loyer ne sera payable qu'à partir de la date de l'acceptation de l'offre.
Les baux seront renouvelables à perpétuité moyennant un loyer variable fixé à la fin de chaque terme, soit d'accord, soit par arbitrage.
En fixant le nouveau loyer, la valeur des bâtiments élevés par le locataire ne sera pas considérée comme un motif d'augmentation de loyer.

EXEMPLE: Si une parcelle de terrain est louée pour une durée de 80 années à prtir du ler Janvier 1907. Dans ce cas, à l'exapiration de ce délai, le locataire aura un droit (à condi- tion d'observer les conditions du bail) d'obtenir un nouveau bail pour une nouvelle période de 80 années, moyennant un loyer modifié, et ainsi à perpétuité.
Le loyer modifié sera calculé sur la valeur du terrain, s'il était libre de construction.

Des offres sont demandées pour les baux emphyteotique dont s'agit; ces cffres devront mentionner la prime que le soumissionaire est disposé à payer au comptant en sus des loyers annuels établis pour chacun des lots. La dite prime devra être payée en un seul versement à la signature du contrat de bail.
Toutes offres doivent être faites par soumis- sion, sur les formules dressées par le Gouverne- ment du Soudan, et doivent être reçues à Khartoum avant le ler Janvier 1907.

Le détail des terrains offerts, le plan de la ville, les conditions de l'adjudication et de la concession, la formule de soumission, spécifica tion du bail, seront à la disposition du Public à partir du ler Octobre 1906, aux lieux ci-après indiqués, durant les heures de bureau. Khartoum-Bureau du Directeur de l'A- griculture et des Terrains (T) et bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Khartoum.
Le Caire Bureau de l'agent du Gouverne- ment du Soudan (T).
Port-Soudan-Bureau de l'Inspecteur (Bu- reau du Gouvernement (T).
Souakim-Bureau du Gouverneur de la Pro- vince et de la Mer Rouge
Wadi-Halfa-Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Halfa.
El-Damer-Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Berber.
Atbara-Bureau du Directeur du Chemin de Fer.
Alexandrie-Bureau de Mr. Macpherson Grant.
Port-Said-Bureau de F. Dixon bey, Repré- sentant du Ministère de la Guerre. Londres-Bureau du Colonel Western, Broadway Chambers, Westminster et le Soudan Court, Imperial Institute.
Suez-Bureau du Capitaine Falconer, Re- présentant du Ministère de la Guerre.

Pour la commodité des acheteurs éventuels les conditions d'adjudication et de concession ont été traduites en arabe et en français et des copies de ces traductions, dans les deux langues, peuvent être obtenues à partir du ler Octobre 1906, moyennant payement de P.T. 5 par copie, aux bureaux mentionnés d ins la liste ci-dessus, qui sont suivis d'une lectro majuscule T.

Des informations supplémentaires peuvent être obtenues après publications des documents ci-dessus mentionnés, moyennant demande. écrite adressée au Directeur de l'Agriculture et des Terrains, à Khartoum.
Aux bureaux marqués d'une astérisque, copies des documents pourront être obtenues à partir du 12. Octobre 1906, moyennant payement de P.T. 5 ou un shelling par copie. 28497-2-1

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
THERAPION

is sold by the principal Chemists throughout the world. Price in England, 2 9 and 4/6.
